sen.j: 日本の住宅（にほんのじゅうたく）
sen.e: Japanese housing
Japanese housing
Japanese housing

sen.j: 日本の住宅は近年までほとんどが木造建築（木造軸組構法、在来工法）の平屋か2階建で、畳のある部屋（和室）を中心に造られてきた。
sen.e: Until recently, most of Japanese houses had been one-story or two-story wooden buildings (using the wood frame-based building method or traditional building method) centered on tatami mat-using rooms (Washitu (Japanese-style rooms)).

Until recently, most Japanese houses had been one-story or two-story wooden buildings (using the wood frame-based building method or traditional building method) centered on tatami mat-using rooms (Washitu (Japanese-style rooms)).

Until recently, most Japanese houses had been one-story or two-story wooden buildings (using the wood frame-based building method or traditional building method) centered on tatami mat-using rooms (Washitsu (Japanese-style rooms)).

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦後、特に高度成長期以降は、生活スタイルや工法の急激な変化に伴い、住宅も大きく変貌している。
sen.e: After WWII or after the high-growth period in particular, Japanese life styles and house-building methods have changed rapidly, altering the styles of the houses drastically as well.
Since WWII, and in particular since the high-growth period, Japanese lifestyles and house-building methods have changed rapidly, altering the styles of the houses drastically as well.
After WWII, and in particular since the high-growth period, Japanese lifestyles and house-building methods have changed rapidly, altering the styles of the houses drastically as well.

sen.j: 生活スタイルとして、和室を造らない場合も多くなっている。
sen.e: Concerning the life style, houses with no Washitsu have been increasing.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Concerning lifestyle, more and more houses have no Washitsu.
Concerning lifestyle, more and more houses have no Washitsu.

sen.j: 工法として、集合住宅（中高層・超高層）では鉄筋コンクリート造・鉄骨造のもの、低層の戸建住宅でも鉄筋コンクリート造やプレハブ工法等のものが多くなっている。
sen.e: Concerning the building methods, reinforced concrete structures or steel-framed structures have been used for building increasingly more condominiums (middle/high-rise or super high-rise buildings), and even for low-rise detached houses, use of reinforced concrete structures or prefabricated building method has increased.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Concerning the building methods, reinforced concrete structures or steel-framed structures have been used for building more and more condominiums (middle/high-rise or super high-rise buildings), and even for low-rise detached houses, use of reinforced concrete structures or prefabricated building methods has increased.

Concerning the building methods, reinforced concrete structures or steel-framed structures have been used for building more and more condominiums (middle/high-rise or super high-rise buildings), and even for low-rise detached houses, use of reinforced concrete structures or prefabricated building methods has increased.

sen.j: 本項では、今日一般的になっている洋風の住宅との比較を念頭に、日本の伝統的な住宅（和風住宅）を中心に記述する。
sen.e: In this article, traditional Japanese style houses (Wa-fu houses) are mainly described, taking into account comparisons with western style houses that have been popular nowadays.
In this article, traditional Japanese-style houses (Wa-fu houses) are mainly described, taking into account comparisons with western-style houses that have been popular nowadays.
In this article, traditional Japanese-style houses (Wa-fu houses) are mainly described, taking into account comparisons with western-style houses that have been popular nowadays.

sen.j: 家具については日本の文化生活を参照。
sen.e: For furniture, refer to "Cultural lives in Japan."
For furniture, refer to "Cultural lives in Japan."
For furniture, refer to "Cultural lives in Japan."

sen.j: 日本住宅史
sen.e: History of Japanese housing
History of Japanese housing
History of Japanese housing

sen.j: 原始・古代（竪穴住居、高床式住居）
sen.e: In the primitive period and ancient times (tateanajukyo (pit dwelling houses) or takayukashiki jukyo (raised-floor houses)）
In the primitive period and ancient times people lived in (tateanajukyo (pit dwelling houses) or takayukashiki jukyo (raised-floor houses)）
In the primitive period and ancient times people lived in (tateanajukyo (pit dwelling houses) or takayukashiki jukyo (raised-floor houses)）

sen.j: 平安時代には貴族の住まいとして寝殿造が成立した。
sen.e: In the Heian period, Shinden-zukuri style was established for nobles' residences.
In the Heian period, Shinden-zukuri style was established for nobles' residences.
In the Heian period, Shinden-zukuri style was established for nobles' residences.

sen.j: 庶民の住居は相変わらず竪穴住居が主流であった。
sen.e: However, the common people still lived mostly in pit dwelling houses.
However, the common people still lived mostly in pit dwelling houses.
However, the common people still lived mostly in pit dwelling houses.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代の武士の住まいは武家造と呼ばれることもあるが、今日では寝殿造を簡略化したものと考えられている。
sen.e: The style of samurai houses in the Kamakura period is sometimes called Buke-zukuri style (Samurai house style), but nowadays it is considered that the style was a simplified version of the Shinden-zukuri style.

The style of samurai houses in the Kamakura period is sometimes called Buke-zukuri style (Samurai house style), but nowadays the style is considered to be a simplified version of the Shinden-zukuri style.

The style of samurai houses in the Kamakura period is sometimes called Buke-zukuri style (Samurai house style), but nowadays the style is considered to be a simplified version of the Shinden-zukuri style.

sen.j: 上層の住宅
sen.e: Residences of people in high classes
Residences of people in high classes
Residences of people in high classes

sen.j: 今日の和風住宅の原型が成立したのは室町時代である。
sen.e: It was in the Muromachi period that the basic patterns of Japanese style houses was established
It was in the Muromachi period that the basic patterns of Japanese style houses were established
It was in the Muromachi period that the basic patterns of Japanese style houses were established

sen.j: 足利義満の邸宅はまだ寝殿造の面影を留めていた。
sen.e: The residence of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA was provided with slight signs of the Shindenzukuri-syle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The residence of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA was provided with slight signs of the Shindenzukuri-syle.
The residence of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA was provided with slight signs of the Shindenzukuri-syle.

sen.j: しかしながら、いわゆる東山文化の時代（応仁の乱前後）の足利義政の邸宅になると、初期書院造と呼ばれるものになる。
sen.e: However, the residence of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA in the period of the Higashi-yama (east mountain) culture (around Onin War) was built in the so-called early shoin-zukuri style.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the residence of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA in the period of the Higashi-yama (east mountain) culture (around Onin War) was built in the so-called early shoin-zukuri style.
However, the residence of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA in the period of the Higashi-yama (east mountain) culture (around Onin War) was built in the so-called early shoin-zukuri style.

sen.j: 畳を敷き詰め、障子戸を用い、床の間などの座敷飾りが造られるようになった。
sen.e: In such a house, tatami mats were laid all over a room, shoji-to (sliding paper doors) were used, and Zashikikazari (a set of decorative features), such as tokonoma (alcove in a traditional Japanese room where art or flowers are displayed) were introduced.

In such a house, tatami mats were laid all over a room, shoji-to (sliding paper doors) were used, and Zashikikazari (a set of decorative features), such as tokonoma (alcove in a traditional Japanese room where art or flowers are displayed) were introduced.

In such a house, tatami mats were laid all over a room, shoji-to (sliding paper doors) were used, and Zashikikazari (a set of decorative features), such as tokonoma (alcove in a traditional Japanese room where art or flowers are displayed) were introduced.

sen.j: 織田信長による天下統一は、住宅史上も画期になったと考えられる。
sen.e: It is considered that the unification of Japan by Nobunaga ODA was epochal in the housing history as well.
As well, the unification of Japan by Nobunaga ODA is considered epochal in the history of housing history.
As well, the unification of Japan by Nobunaga ODA is considered epochal in the history of housing history.

sen.j: 信長の安土城や、豊臣秀吉の大坂城などにおいて身分の序列を著し権力者の威厳を示すため、書院造が完成した。
sen.e: The Shoin-zukuri style was established for clarifying the social status orders of persons and for showing dignity of the person in authority in Azuchi-jo Castle by Nobunaga or Osaka-jo Castle by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

The Shoin-zukuri style was established for clarifying the social status orders of persons and for showing dignity of the person in authority in Azuchi-jo Castle built by Nobunaga or Osaka-jo Castle built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

The Shoin-zukuri style was established for clarifying the social status orders of persons and for showing dignity of the person in authority in Azuchi-jo Castle built by Nobunaga or Osaka-jo Castle built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 家臣は城下町に住むよう命じられ、狩野永徳の洛中洛外図屏風などから、都市建築（町屋、武家屋敷など）も発達してきたことが伺える。
sen.e: Vassals are ordered to live in castle towns, and it is supposed, for example, from Rakuchu Rakugaizu Byobu (urban areas and suburbs of Kyoto, a folding screen) by Eitoku KANO, that buildings in urban areas (such as Machiya (traditional townhouses found mainly in Kyoto) and samurai residences) had progressed as well.

Vassals were ordered to live in castle towns, and it is supposed, for example, from Rakuchu Rakugaizu Byobu (urban areas and suburbs of Kyoto, a folding screen) by Eitoku KANO, that buildings in urban areas (such as Machiya (traditional townhouses found mainly in Kyoto) and samurai residences) had progressed as well.

Vassals were ordered to live in castle towns, and it is supposed, for example, from Rakuchu Rakugaizu Byobu (urban areas and suburbs of Kyoto, a folding screen) by Eitoku KANO, that buildings in urban areas (such as Machiya (traditional townhouses found mainly in Kyoto) and samurai residences) had progressed as well.

sen.j: 上層の住まいとして書院造が定着し、江戸時代以降、茶室の要素を採り入れたいわゆる数寄屋造り（数寄屋風書院）の住宅も造られるようになった。
sen.e: Shoin-zukuri style was established for residences for persons in high classes, and in the Edo period and later, houses became also built in the Sukiya-zukuri style where factors of tea rooms were introduced (Sukiya-type Shoin-zukuri style)

The Shoin-zukuri style was established for residences for persons in high classes, and during the Edo period and later, houses also came to be built in the Sukiya-zukuri style where factors of tea rooms were introduced (Sukiya-type Shoin-zukuri style).

The Shoin-zukuri style was established for residences for persons in high classes, and during the Edo period and later, houses also came to be built in the Sukiya-zukuri style where factors of tea rooms were introduced (Sukiya-type Shoin-zukuri style).

sen.j: 庶民の住宅
sen.e: Houses of the common people
Houses of the common people
Houses of the common people

sen.j: （民家の項も参照）
sen.e: (Refer to private houses as well.)
(Refer to private houses as well.)
(Refer to private houses as well.)

sen.j: 中世の絵巻物などに庶民の町屋が描かれている。
sen.e: Machiya houses of the common people in urban areas are depicted on picture scrolls and others.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Machiya houses of the common people in urban areas are depicted on picture scrolls and others.
Machiya houses of the common people in urban areas are depicted on picture scrolls and others in the early feudal period.
sen.cmt: 「中世の」in the early feudal periodを追加。日本の時代区分としての「中世」は鎌倉、室町時代なので、このように表記しました。

sen.j: しかしながら、それを見ると、平屋建、板葺き屋根など非常に簡素なものだったことが伺える。
sen.e: According to them, it is supposed that they were quite simple, for example, one-story and shingle roof (a roof made with many layered small wood plates) houses.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to the depictions, it is supposed that the houses of common people were quite simple; for example, one-story and having a shingle roof (a roof made with many layered small wooden plates).
According to the depictions, it is supposed that the houses of common people were quite simple; for example, one-story and having a shingle roof (a roof made with many layered small wooden plates).

sen.j: 江戸時代に入ると、庶民の住宅も次第に発達していった。
sen.e: Entering the Edo period, the houses of the common people had progressed gradually.
Entering the Edo period, the houses of the common people had progressed gradually.
Entering the Edo period, the houses of the common people had progressed gradually.

sen.j: 大まかに言えば、関西の住宅の方が質が高く、構造や工法が次第に関東にも影響を与えていった。
sen.e: Roughly speaking, the quality of such houses was higher in the Kansai area, and its structure and building methods had gradually affected those in the Kanto area as well.
Roughly speaking, the quality of such houses was higher in the Kansai area, and their structure and building methods had gradually affected those in the Kanto area as well.
Roughly speaking, the quality of such houses was higher in the Kansai area, and their structure and building methods had gradually affected those in the Kanto area as well.

sen.j: 近世初期の関東で一般的な農民の住まいは、土間に囲炉裏を作り、床にむしろなどを敷くようなものも多かった。
sen.e: In the Kanto area in the early modern period, ordinary dwellings of farmers were mostly built in such a way that an irori fireplace (open hearth) was made on doma (dirt floor) and straw mats were laid on the floors.

In the Kanto area in the early modern period, ordinary dwellings of farmers were mostly built in such a way that an irori fireplace (open hearth) was made on doma (dirt floor) and straw mats were laid on the floors.

In the Kanto area in the early modern period, ordinary dwellings of farmers were mostly built in such a way that an irori fireplace (open hearth) was made on doma (dirt floor) and straw mats were laid on the floors.

sen.j: 工法も古代・中世と余り変わらず、掘立柱を立て、茅葺で屋根や壁を葺くようなものであった。
sen.e: Having remained little changed since the primitive period and ancient times, these houses were built with hottate bashira (an earthfast post) and using thatch for the roof and walls.
Having changed little since the primitive period and ancient times, these houses were built with hottate bashira (an earthfast post) and using thatch for the roof and walls.
Having changed little since the ancient times and the early feudal period, these houses were built with hottate bashira (an earthfast post) and using thatch for the roof and walls.
sen.cmt: 「中世」 the early feudal periodを追加。日本の時代区分としての「中世」は鎌倉、室町時代なので、このように表記しました。

sen.j: 経済的に向上するに従って、住宅の質も次第に上がり、土間を台所や作業場などに使い、床を造り食事や就寝に使う部屋が造られていった。
sen.e: Corresponding to economic advancement, the quality of these houses had been improved gradually: Dirt floors became used for a kitchen and work, and with raised floors built, rooms for eating food and for sleeping became provided.

Corresponding to economic advancement, the quality of these houses had been improved gradually: Dirt floors came to be used only for kitchens and workspaces, and raised floors were built for rooms for eating food and for sleeping.

Corresponding to economic advancement, the quality of these houses had been improved gradually: Dirt floors came to be used only for kitchens and workspaces, and raised floors were built for rooms for eating food and for sleeping.

sen.j: 高い技能を持った職人が関与するようになり、工法も礎石の上に柱を据え、梁 (建築)を複雑に組み合わせて造るように変わった。
sen.e: As craftsmen with a high level of skill became engaged in building such houses, houses became built in the way that pillars were placed on foundation stones and beams were assembled in complex ways.
As craftsmen with a high level of skill became engaged in building such houses, houses became built in the way that pillars were placed on foundation stones and beams were assembled in complex ways.
As craftsmen with a high level of skill became engaged in building such houses, houses became built in the way that pillars were placed on foundation stones and beams were assembled in complex ways.

sen.j: ただし、土壁や茅葺屋根は家族や集落の仲間と共同で造ることも多かった。
sen.e: However, mud walls and thatched roofs were often made in cooperation with family members and persons in the community.
However, mud walls and thatched roofs were often made in cooperation with family members and persons in the community.
However, mud walls and thatched roofs were often made in cooperation with family members and persons in the community.

sen.j: 江戸時代後期以降になると「田の字型」の間取りが広く普及していった。
sen.e: In the latter half of the Edo period and later, the floor layout with the shape of the Chinese character 田 had become used widely.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the latter half of the Edo period and later, the floor layout with the shape of the Chinese character 田 came into wide use.
In the latter half of the Edo period and later, the floor layout with the shape of the Chinese character 田 came into wide use.

sen.j: この間取りは結婚や葬儀など人が多く集まる行事に使うことを意識したものである。
sen.e: This layout was adopted considering using the house in events, such as wedding ceremonies and funeral ceremonies, in which many persons participated.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This layout was adopted in consideration of using the house for events with many participants, such as wedding ceremonies and funeral ceremonies.
This layout was adopted in consideration of using the house for events with many participants, such as wedding ceremonies and funeral ceremonies.

sen.j: 用途に合わせて襖を開け閉めして用いた。
sen.e: The fusuma sliding doors were opened or closed for the necessity of using these rooms.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The fusuma sliding doors were opened or closed according to the necessity of using these rooms.
The fusuma sliding doors were opened or closed according to the necessity of using these rooms.

sen.j: 今日、伝統的な民家として民家園などに保存されているものには、「田の字型」のタイプが多く見られる。
sen.e: Today, many of the traditional private houses maintained, for example, in minka-en (a place where traditional private houses are exhibited), are provided with the floor layout with the shape of the Chinese character 田.

Today, many traditional private houses maintained in, for example, minka-en (a place where traditional private houses are exhibited), are provided with a floor layout having the shape of the Chinese character 田.

Today, many traditional private houses maintained in, for example, minka-en (a place where traditional private houses are exhibited), are provided with a floor layout having the shape of the Chinese character 田.

sen.j: 江戸時代には住宅にも身分による統制が行われていた。
sen.e: In the Edo period, social status-based control was conducted in building a house.
In the Edo period, social status-based control was followed in building a house.
In the Edo period, social status-based control was followed in building a house.

sen.j: 例えば武士や名主クラスの農家では、床の間などを造ることが許されたが、庶民が床の間を造ることや瓦葺屋根にすることなどは贅沢だとして禁止されることが一般的だった。
sen.e: For example, samurai and farmers in the nanushi (village headman) class were permitted to provide tokonoma (alcove in a traditional Japanese room where art or flowers are displayed), but the common people were generally prohibited from providing tokonoma nor tiled roofs, for that reason that they were too extravagant for the common people to provide for.

For example, samurai and farmers in the nanushi (village headman) class were permitted to provide tokonoma (alcove in a traditional Japanese room where art or flowers are displayed), but the common people were generally prohibited from providing tokonoma and tiled roofs, because they were too extravagant for the common people.

For example, samurai and farmers in the nanushi (village headman) class were permitted to provide tokonoma (alcove in a traditional Japanese room where art or flowers are displayed), but the common people were generally prohibited from providing tokonoma and tiled roofs, because they were too extravagant for the common people.

sen.j: （ただし、防火のため瓦葺屋根を奨励されたり、義務付けられた町もある）
sen.e: (However, in some towns, it was promoted or obliged to provide tiled roofs for fire prevention.)
(However, in some towns, provision of tiled roofs was promoted or obligatory, for fire prevention.)
(However, in some towns, provision of tiled roofs was promoted or obligatory, for fire prevention.)

sen.j: 近代以降の住宅
sen.e: In modern times and later
In modern times and later
In modern times and later

sen.j: 明治時代になると建築に関する封建的な規制もなくなり、資力に応じて住宅を造るようになった。
sen.e: Entering the Meiji period, feudalistic restrictions on building houses were removed and it became possible to build houses depending on funds available.
Entering the Meiji period, feudalistic restrictions on building houses were removed and it became possible to build houses depending on funds available.
Entering the Meiji period, feudalistic restrictions on building houses were removed and it became possible to build houses depending on funds available.

sen.j: 西洋建築の技術にも刺激され、大工道具の質も上がり、職人の交流も活発になったことなどで、建築の質は全体に向上していった。
sen.e: Affected by technologies in European architecture, carpenters' tools had been improved and craftsmen had become interacted with each other actively, improving quality of buildings as a whole.
Affected by technologies in European architecture, carpenters' tools had been improved and craftsmen had interacted with each other actively, improving the quality of buildings as a whole.
Affected by technologies in European architecture, carpenters' tools had been improved and craftsmen had interacted with each other actively, improving the quality of buildings as a whole.

sen.j: 明治時代に洋風の住宅（西洋館）に住むのは、政治家、実業家などごく限られた階層の一部の者であり、ほとんどは和風住宅であった。
sen.e: In the Meiji period, only a small number of persons in limited social classes, such as politicians and successful businessmen, lived in western style houses, and most people lived in traditional Japanese style houses.

In the Meiji period, only a small number of persons in limited social classes, such as politicians and successful businessmen, lived in western style houses, and most people lived in traditional Japanese style houses.

In the Meiji period, only a small number of persons in limited social classes, such as politicians and successful businessmen, lived in western style houses, and most people lived in traditional Japanese style houses.

sen.j: 大正時代以降、サラリーマン、都市知識人らが洋風の生活に憧れ、一部洋風を採り入れた和洋折衷の文化住宅が都市郊外に多く造られるようになった。
sen.e: In the Taisho period and later, salaried men and intellectuals in urban areas longed for western style lives, and new style houses in which western elements were taken partially in became built in suburbs.

In the Taisho period and later, salaried men and intellectuals in urban areas longed for western style lives, and new style houses which partially adopted western elements came to be built in suburbs.

In the Taisho period and later, salaried men and intellectuals in urban areas longed for western style lives, and new style houses which partially adopted western elements came to be built in suburbs.

sen.j: しかし、家の中では靴を脱ぎ、畳でくつろぐといった生活スタイル自体はほとんど変わらなかった。
sen.e: However, the life style in which shoes are taken off within houses and people relax on tatami mats has remained almost unchanged.
However, the lifestyle in which shoes are taken off within houses and people relax on tatami mats has remained almost unchanged.
However, the lifestyle in which shoes are taken off within houses and people relax on tatami mats has remained almost unchanged.

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦後、住宅難の中で公団住宅など、大量供給型の住宅が造られた。
sen.e: During housing shortage after WWII, mass-production type houses, such as those in apartment buildings constructed by the Housing Corporation, were built.
During the housing shortage after WWII, mass-production-type houses were built, such as those in apartment buildings constructed by Housing Corporations.
During the housing shortage after WWII, mass-production-type houses were built, such as those in apartment buildings constructed by Housing Corporations.

sen.j: 合理的な生活を目指してダイニングキッチンなどが新たに工夫された。
sen.e: Eat-in kitchens and others were introduced aiming at making lives more rational.
Eat-in kitchens and other features were introduced, aiming at making lives more rational.
Eat-in kitchens and other features were introduced, aiming at making lives more rational.

sen.j: かつては床の間のない家はほとんど考えられなかった。
sen.e: In the past, houses without tokonoma were almost unimaginable.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the past, houses without tokonoma were almost unimaginable.
In the past, houses without tokonoma were almost unimaginable.

sen.j: しかし、今日では洋風の住まいが普及し、新築の家は、和室と共に床の間のある例も減少してきている。
sen.e: However, nowadays, as western style houses have been built widely, those with tokonoma as well as Japanese style rooms have decreased.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, nowadays, as western style houses have been built widely, those with tokonoma as well as Japanese style rooms have decreased.
However, nowadays, as western style houses have been built widely, those with tokonoma as well as Japanese style rooms have decreased.

sen.j: また、かつての住宅は農家でも町屋でも、生業と結びついた職住一致のものが多かった。
sen.e: In the past, many of the houses, for examples, farmers' houses and Machiya houses, were a place where persons lived and worked for earning their living.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the past, many houses, such as farmers' houses and Machiya houses, were place where persons lived and worked for earning their living.
In the past, many houses, such as farmers' houses and Machiya houses, were place where persons lived and worked for earning their living.

sen.j: しかしながら、現在は職住分離の方が主流になっている。
sen.e: However, nowadays, most of the houses are only for living.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, nowadays, most houses are only for living.
However, nowadays, most houses are only for living.

sen.j: 住宅の種類
sen.e: House types
House types
House types

sen.j: 日本の住宅の種類には一戸建て、集合住宅（マンション、アパート、団地、公団住宅）、長屋、文化住宅などがある。
sen.e: The houses in Japan include, detached houses, condominiums (so-called Manshon, apartments, Danchi (apartment complexes) and Kodanjutaku (apartment buildings constructed by the Housing Corporation), Nagaya (houses in a row) and Bunka-jutaku (new style houses).

Houses in Japan include detached houses, condominiums (so-called Mansions, apartments, Danchi (apartment complexes) and Kodanjutaku (apartment buildings constructed by a Housing Corporation)), Nagaya (rowhouses), and Bunka-jutaku (new style houses).

Houses in Japan include detached houses, condominiums (so-called Mansions, apartments, Danchi (apartment complexes) and Kodanjutaku (apartment buildings constructed by a Housing Corporation)), Nagaya (rowhouses), and Bunka-jutaku (new style houses).

sen.j: 住宅の集まりを指して集落、部落、地区などと言う。
sen.e: The houses located in a small area are called Shuraku (a settlement), buraku (a hamlet) or Chiku (an area).
Houses located in a small area are called Shuraku (a settlement), buraku (a hamlet), or Chiku (an area).
Houses located in a small area are called Shuraku (a settlement), buraku (a hamlet), or Chiku (an area).

sen.j: 古くからの習慣で、住居が建っている場所や住人の職業などで区別して商家、町家、農家などとも言う。
sen.e: According to time-honored custom, the terms of merchants' houses, Machiya houses and farmers' houses are also used, depending on the place where the houses are located or the jobs of the persons who live in the houses.

According to time-honored custom, the terms merchants' houses, Machiya houses, and farmers' houses are also used, depending on the place where the houses are located or the jobs of the persons who live in the houses.

According to time-honored custom, the terms merchants' houses, Machiya houses, and farmers' houses are also used, depending on the place where the houses are located or the jobs of the persons who live in the houses.

sen.j: 屋根（茅葺き、瓦、トタン）
sen.e: A roof (thatch, tile or galvanized iron)
Roof (thatch, tile, or galvanized iron)

sen.j: 天井、天井裏
sen.e: Ceilings, the spaces between a roof and the ceilings
Ceilings, the spaces between the roof and ceilings

Bases

sen.j: 柱、梁 (建築)、鴨居 大黒柱、床柱

Pillars, beams, Kamoi (lintels), a central pillar, an alcove post

sen.j: 床（板の間、むしろ、畳、土間、フローリング）
sen.e: Floors (wood floors, Mushiro (straw) mats, Tatami mats, dirty floors, or flooring)
Floors (wood floors, Mushiro (straw) mats, Tatami mats, dirt floors, or flooring)
Floors (wood floors, Mushiro (straw) mats, Tatami mats, dirt floors, or flooring)

sen.j: 壁（砂壁、土壁、板壁、漆喰、羽目板）
sen.e: Walls (sand walls, mud walls, board walls, plaster-coated walls, or clapboard walls)
Walls (sand walls, mud walls, board walls, plaster-coated walls, or clapboard walls)
Walls (sand walls, mud walls, board walls, plaster-coated walls, or clapboard walls)

sen.j: 建具（襖、障子、板戸、雨戸）
sen.e: Fittings (sliding doors, paper sliding-doors, wooden doors, and sliding shutters)
Fittings (sliding doors, paper sliding-doors, wooden doors, and sliding shutters)

sen.j: 玄関（たたき、式台、下駄箱、靴箱）
sen.e: An entrance (a hard-packed concrete floor, Shikidai (a step), Getabako (a box for storing Japanese wooden footgears) and a shoe box)
Entrance (hard-packed concrete floor, Shikidai (a step), Getabako (a box for storing Japanese wooden footwear) and a shoe box)

sen.j: 階段、箱階段、螺旋階段、非常階段、はしご

sen.j: 部屋（寝室、床の間、居間・リビング、浴室・バスルーム、台所、便所・便所、地下室）
sen.e: Rooms (bedrooms, Tokonoma, a living room, a bath room, a kitchen, a lavatory, an underground room)

sen.j: 収納スペース（押入れ、納戸、蔵・倉、物置、クローゼット、ウォークイン・クローゼット）
sen.e: Storage spaces (Oshiire (a space mainly storing futon, with sliding doors), Nando (a room for storing furniture and/or clothes), Kura (a warehouse), Monooki (a house for storing tools), closets, and/or walking-in closets)

sen.j: 民家、合掌造、町屋 (商家)、長屋

sen.j: 日本庭園（庭石、借景、枯山水）

Japanese style gardens (garden rocks, burrowed landscapes, and karesansui (dry garden style))

sen.j: 縁側、縁台、飛び石、手水（ちょうず）、灯籠
sen.e: Engawa (a narrow wooden passageway along the edge of a house facing the garden), Endai (outdoor benches), Tobi-ishi (stepping-stones), Chozu (water basins), toro (garden lanterns)

sen.j: 日本統治時代を経験した日本統治時代 (台湾)、日本統治時代の朝鮮、樺太といった地域では、現在でも日本家屋が現存している
sen.e: In Taiwan, Korea and Sakhalin where Japan ruled once, Japanese style houses still remain even today.
